questions.question: A network that connects LANs in different countries is most likely a WAN.
Which unit of data stores a single value that can be a 0 or a 1?
What is one of the disadvantages of a peer-to-peer network compared to a server-based network?
options: more difficult to setup and install

questions.question: Which component, located on the motherboard, carries out all the instructions provided by computer programs?
Which component manages the details of communicating with the NIC hardware to send and receive data to and from network media?

You have just started a new business. You need to have three to four workstations available for your employees who simply need to share some files and a printer, but you don't have a large budget. Security is not a major concern, but costs are. Which network model would be the most appropriate for your situation?

You want a fast CPU for the new computer you are building and your motherboard only has one CPU socket. To increase the processing power, you need a CPU that provides more than one processor. What type of CPU are you looking for?
When data is being prepared for transmission onto the network, it is broken into small pieces and a header and trailer are added to each piece to help identify it. What is this process called?
Which of the following are examples of input devices? (Choose all that apply.)
Air waves are an example of what type of network component?

You are building a gaming computer and you want to install a dedicated graphics card that has a fast GPU and 4GB of memory on board. You need to make sure that you have the right connector available on your motherboard. What type of connector would be appropriate?
Using the physical mail analogy, what part of an address on an envelope is most like the IP address?
Each component of a computer is designed to perform only one specific taskâ€”either input, processing, or output.
Which part of the network communication process is responsible for sending and receiving data to and from the network media?
What is one of the disadvantages of a server-based network compared to a peer-to-peer network?

You're the network administrator for a company located in Arizona that has just opened an office in Texas. You need to make sure that the two locations can communicate. What type of network are you implementing?
In order to find out your MAC address, you should open a command prompt and type ipconfig /all.
Which of the following are examples of output devices? (Choose all that apply.)
What makes a computer a 'server' is the fact that it has a server operating system installed on it.
Every NIC has a unique address that consists of a 12-digit hexadecimal value. What is this address called?
What command would you issue from a command prompt to see a listing of the computers in your workgroup?
Windows 10 is an example of which of the following?

The XYZ company has two offices, one in Chicago, and a brand new office in Pittsburgh. To connect the two offices, they will need a dedicated line, probably leased from the phone company. What type of network will they be implementing to connect their two offices?
Which part of the network communication process is responsible for sending and receiving data to and from the network media?

You are the network administrator for a company and you want to separate the traffic from the accounting department from the rest of the network. However, the accounting department still needs to have access to other network resources. What type of network do you need to implement?
An extranet is a private network, such as a school or company network, in which the devices and servers are available only to users connected to the internal network.
What command would you issue from the command prompt to test whether your computer has connectivity to the network?
What does a switch do if it doesn't find the destination MAC address in its switching table?
options: sends an ARP to learn the MAC address
forwards the frame out all ports
sends an error to the sending device

questions.question: Just as a switch keeps records of MAC addresses that it has learned, so does your computer. What protocol does your computer use to learn MAC addresses?
Which of the following is true about hubs?
options: They can handle several computer conversations simultaneously.
Devices on a hub have to share the available bandwidth.
They can operate in full-duplex and half-duplex mode.
They maintain a table of MAC addresses.

questions.question: Which of the following are features of a router? (Choose all that apply)
What type of frame is addressed to a specific computer?
What is the purpose of the default route?
options: It's a route set by Microsoft so that all information comes to their servers first.
It's a route that all routers use to get to the Internet.
It's where the router sends all packets with destination addresses of which it has no knowledge.
It serves as a guideline for how to configure routes.

questions.question: When a NIC is in promiscuous mode, it will process only the frames in which the destination MAC address matches its own MAC address.
What component of the computer contains a MAC address?
If a router receives a packet and it does not have an entry in its routing table for the destination network, it will send the packet to its default route, if configured.
What does a switch store in its switching table?
options: The frame's destination MAC address and the port it was received on.
The frame's source IP address and the port it was received on.
The frame's destination IP address and the port it was received on.
The frame's source MAC address and the port it was received on.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of a hub?
options: receives the signal from a connected computer on one of its ports
transmits the frame out the correct port

questions.question: In some wireless network configurations, a computer must send a special message to the AP before it can transmit data. What is this message called?
If a router receives a packet and it does not have an entry in its routing table for the destination network, it will send the packet to its default route, if configured.
Which of the following is true about a NIC?
options: For outgoing messages, it converts frame data into bit signals.
For incoming messages, it creates frames from packets.
For incoming messages, it adds a source and destination MAC address.
For outgoing messages, it assembles bit signals into frames.

questions.question: Routers do not forward broadcast packets.
How does a switch 'learn' MAC addresses?
options: The switch uses a mathematical formula to determine what the MAC address would be for each computer connected to it.
The switch comes loaded with the most frequently used addresses.
It reads the source address and keeps a record of which port the sending computer is on.
All the MAC addresses must be entered manually.

questions.question: What does it mean if the full-duplex indicator on a switch port is on?
options: The port can transmit and receive frames simultaneously.
The MAC address table is full.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about routers? (Choose all that apply.)
options: break up a network into functional groups
allow computers on different networks to communicate
forward broadcasts out all connected ports

questions.question: When referring to network bandwidth, what is the basic unit of measurement?
What command issued from the command prompt will show the route that a packet travels from the issuing computer to another computer?
A computer's default gateway setting is the MAC address of a router on a remote network.
Which device receives a frame and reads the source and destination MAC addresses before forwarding the frame out another port?
A wireless access point is most like which other network device, in that all computers send signals through it to communicate with other computers?
The name assigned to a wireless network is called the SSID.
A MAC address is composed of two 24-bit numbers. What does the first 24-bit number represent?
options: The address it uses for a multicast packet.
The decryption key used for security purposes.
A unique serial number assigned by the manufacturer.

questions.question: What is in an Ethernet frame's trailer?
Which Ethernet standard specifies speeds of 40 and 100 Gbps and can run up to 7 meters over copper?
What is the media access method used by Ethernet?
In a token ring network, what is the central device called?
Which of the following is NOT a field in an Ethernet frame header?
In which topology does a central device communicate with two or more other devices and is used in WANs where a main office has connections to several branch offices via a router?
With which kind of Wi-Fi antennas does the signal radiate out with equal strength in all directions?
What happens to Wi-Fi signals when they pass through solid objects like walls?
options: Diffraction occurs and the signals are amplified.
Absorption occurs and the signals attenuate.

questions.question: When a wireless computer uses a peer-to-peer connection to directly connect to another wireless computer, it is operating in what mode?
What type of logical topology is at work when using an Ethernet hub?
A collision can occur on a switch only if the switch is operating in full-duplex mode.
In a physical bus topology, both ends of the medium must be terminated in order to prevent what?
Which of the following is true about collisions?
options: They are a problem with Token Ring networks.
They can occur on Ethernet half-duplex networks.
They can only happen with switches.

questions.question: Which of the following is the physical topology that is daisy-chained like a bus where the cabling is brought around from the last device to the first device?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of Unshielded Twisted Pair cabling?
options: contains four pairs of copper wire

questions.question: In wireless networks, what type of media access control is used?
Which of the following is NOT an advantage of a physical star?
options: centralized monitoring and management of traffic

questions.question: What is an advantage of a point-to-point topology?
options: data travels on a dedicated link

questions.question: When discussing Ethernet standards, what does the XBaseY terminology refer to?
options: the transmission speed, the length or type of cabling, and the type of transmissions
the transmission speed, the type of transmissions, and the length or type of cabling
the length or type of cabling, the type of transmissions, and the transmission speed
the length or type of cabling, the transmission speed, and the type of transmissions

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true about 2.5/5GBaseT Ethernet?
options: It has a maximum distance of 100 meters.
It requires at least Cat 6A cabling.
It can be used as an uplink for 802.11ac networks.

questions.question: A point-to-point topology is typically used for WAN connections or wireless bridges.
A network's physical topology refers to the arrangement of the cabling and how the devices connect to each other.
The physical bus topology is no longer used because it required extra cable and a central device to connect all the computers.
What is the most common topology and technology combination in use today?
A network's logical topology often depends on the central device's electronics.
Which Ethernet standard specifies speeds of 40 and 100 Gbps and can run up to 7 meters over copper?
A collision can occur on a switch only if the switch is operating in full-duplex mode.
In a physical bus topology, both ends of the medium must be terminated in order to prevent what?
Which of the following is true about collisions?
options: They are a problem with Token Ring networks.
They can occur on Ethernet half-duplex networks.
They can only happen with switches.

questions.question: Which of the following is the physical topology that is daisy-chained like a bus where the cabling is brought around from the last device to the first device?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of Unshielded Twisted Pair cabling?
options: contains four pairs of copper wire

questions.question: In wireless networks, what type of media access control is used?
In which topology does a central device communicate with two or more other devices and is used in WANs where a main office has connections to several branch offices via a router?
What happens to Wi-Fi signals when they pass through solid objects like walls?
options: Diffraction occurs and the signals are amplified.
Absorption occurs and the signals attenuate.

questions.question: In a token ring network, what is the central device called?
What is a disadvantage of using fiber-optic cabling versus twisted-pair cabling?
options: limited to shorter distances due to high attenuation

questions.question: What type of wiring should be used for a high-speed connection between two buildings?
Wireless and wired networks are both susceptible to RFI.
Which of the following are components of wireless networks? (Choose all that apply.)
You hand a technician a crossover cable to make a connection between devices. Which device pair are you most likely asking him to connect?

A signal has just been received from the WAN link on your network. Using the given components, which of the following shows the path that the signal would take from the WAN to a workstation on your network? Assume all components are used at least once and that some components may be used more than once. 1-backbone cabling 2-entrance facility 3-MDF 4-horizontal wiring 5-IDF 6-work area
Compared to SMF, MMF cable costs more and generally works with laser-based emitters but spans the longest distances and is used in higher-bandwidth applications.
Which type of interference is caused by wires in the same cabling bundle?
What is the maximum bandwidth for a network cable using category 5e UTP cable?
